newsitem.title: INDIA: India says pipeline with Oman on hold.
newsitem.headline: India says pipeline with Oman on hold.

text.p: India said on Wednesday that the $4-billion Oman-India natural gas pipeline project has been put on hold in the absence of proper technology.
"For the time being, that project we are keeping it in abeyance till the technology is available," Indian Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral told reporters.
"At the moment that technolgy is not available the world over."
Gujral spoke on the second day of a four-day visit to India by Oman's Sultan Qaboos bin Said.
The two countries signed a memorandum of understanding in 1993 to build a pipeline between the two nations under the Arabian Sea.
A Foreign Ministry spokesman said earlier this month that the two governments had decided in 1996 to set up a joint committee of experts to study whether the project was feasible.
Omani officials said the Gulf state has spent $70 million to 80 million on the feasibility study and was not likely to spend any more on it.
According to the original plan, the proposed pipeline would be more than 1,300 km (813 miles) long and lie up to two miles under the ocean's surface.
